text: From a paraeducator in Dubuque- "Hey, Kimberly! I am a paraprofessional (also known as a teacher's aide), who works with kiddos who have autism. I have a teaching degree, but got in as a full-time para, and fell in love with my position. I want to remain as a para because I love it so much. I don't know how much information you may know about us, but we are often referred to as teachers' "eyes, ears, arms, and legs." We are also the "frontliners." We wear many hats, and our jobs can be quite challenging...just as it is for teachers (it's not for everybody). Sometimes, we are even mistaken for being teachers. In my medium sized school district, in Iowa, there is a para for every two teachers. There are secretary, health/nurse, multi-cat (gen. ed.), behavioral program, autism program, library, and security paras. Some of us work more one-on-one with students, while others stay with a general ed. class all day. Currently, our district's paras are trying to rejoin the union that we were previously a part of. We lost our union 2 years ago, due to one vote! If a person doesn't vote, it's considered a no vote, which is crazy! After 2 years, our paras can join a union again, which we are trying to do. Our collective bargaining rights were stripped away, in Iowa, back in 2017. They need to be brought back! We can only negotiate wages, and to a certain extent. Language and benefits are off the table, during negotiations. This does not give us much to work with. Some of our goals that we are trying to achieve are: a higher income, better benefits (it seems that paras are the only ones that have to pay for single payer insurance, in our district, and the family insurance is incredibly high...it takes most of our paycheck), as well as summer unemployment (our state reps. are trying to work on this for us...Iowa would be the first in the nation to do this for paraprofessionals, which is amazing). Our administration would love to be able to do more to support everybody (just like other schools), but our state funding is so low, and it barely covers inflation. Often teachers are put in the spotlight as far as trying to get better income, and paras seem to always be left behind. We feel we need a voice, too. We are a part of the glue that holds things together. Teachers definitely deserve better pay for what they do; they're incredible! I was a substitute teacher for quite some time, before I was hired as a para; I did long-term subbing. I know what their job entails, and they deserve better, but in my opinion and in others', paras should be paid at least half of what a teacher makes. Now, I am a member of an international paraeducator Facebook group. Some para members, across the US, have mentioned that their administrators and teachers pushed to eliminate a lot of their paras, and replace them with more teachers. Shortly after, teachers realized that it was a mistake on their part to push for that, and that they actually needed paras. Their jobs were even more challenging without them by their side, and they regretted their actions. Paras love their jobs...they love their kiddos. They're passionate about what they do, but many are financially struggling (not just in Iowa). Not everyone has a spouse to help support them. Actually, a lot of our paras are either single (like myself) or a single parent. Some are even the breadwinner. Many have to work 2-3 jobs just to try to make ends meet. There has to be a better answer. Some have student loan debt, medical bills, etc. in addition to their regular bills. I added up my paychecks from the last school year...I made $12,500, which included several trainings, summer school, and the times that I was able to stay a little later than my normal hours. What I make is what most of our district paras make. Our paras are considered to be the second highest paid in the state of Iowa! We are literally working at poverty level, according to our state reps. We deserve a livable income! According to my bank's financial stability rule...20/30/50. I can put $200 towards savings per month, $300 towards housing, and $500 towards everything else. According to my bank's housing calculator, I can only afford a $51k house. I would love to be able to purchase my parents' home (my childhood home), that I currently live in, when they decide to move, in the next several years. For the past 10 years, I've not been able to save much money due to my $85k student loan debt that I have acquired, and have been desperately trying to pay it off. Very soon I will be debt-free, and would love to be able to purchase a car, a home. However, without any change financially, I won't be able to afford to purchase my family's house, in the near future (at least not on my para income alone). This concerns me greatly. Please keep paras in mind while running for Senate. If possible, could you please not only put teachers in the spotlight, but paras as well? Please be an advocate for us! I feel a lot of people don't even know what a paraprofessional is and how important we are to our students. We wish more people knew what our jobs entailed and how valuable we are. We need to elect people who love and support our public schools, our kiddos, our teachers, our paras and staff...who have a drive, a good heart, and will listen to everyone's voice...taking action, when need be. I wish you all the best in your endeavors, and will continue to follow your page. Thank you for all you do!"
